newsitem.title: USA: US Midwest direct hogs seen steady-off $1- dealers.
newsitem.headline: US Midwest direct hogs seen steady-off $1- dealers.

text.p: U.S. Midwest direct cash hog prices Wednesday were seen steady to $1.00 per cwt lower on continued light packer demand and projections for increased marketings, livestock dealers said.
Marketings were seen expanded by improved weather conditions in the Midwest following recent frigid temperatures and snow, which had slowed movement earlier in the week.

Interior Iowa and southern Minnesota top prices for hogs delivered to the plant were seen $1.00 lower and could range $54.50 to $55.50. Illinois top prices at the plant were seen steady and could range $55.50 to $56.00.
Indiana/Ohio top plant prices for hogs were expected steady and could range $54.00 to $55.00.
Packers reportedly have enough hogs to work with and were bidding lower to offset soft pork demand, market sources said.
There were 60.25 loads of pork and 8.0 loads of trimmings reported sold near midday at mixed prices, USDA said in the U.S. carlot pork report.
Interior Iowa and southern Minnesota hog receipts Wednesday were estimated at 105,000 head, compared with 90,000 a week ago and 101,000 a year ago, USDA reported.
